---
title: Im in the middle of
categories: Discussion
tags: ['middle', 'gming', 'first', 'course']
author: Troy Morris
link: https://plus.google.com/+TroyMorris/posts/hdQ73Grh6QR
published: 2018-09-09T01:17:15.984Z

imagelink: []
thumblinks: []
---

I&#39;m in the middle of GMing for the first time (in any game ever)made. Of course, I went home brewbecause why not?<br /><br />Currently, I&#39;m in need of a dungeon I can throw a Minotaur into as the main monster. But I have a full schedule until the next session.<br /><br />I am wondering if anyone has any recommended dungeons I can download (willing to pay).<br /><br />Thanks in advance!
<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/111734437461360625141_photo.jpg'> Michael Esperum</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-09 06:34:31 (edited: 2018-09-09 06:34:31)</cite></p>
        <p>You should probably just think about sights, sounds and smells (and other sensory experiences), and think of the reason they want to arrive at the middle/get through  it.<br /><br />--------    -------<br /><br />You could also use <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/108530078404383929502" oid="108530078404383929502">Jason Cordova</a></span>&#39;s Labyrinth move:<br /><br />When you attempt to navigate the labyrinth, describe how you do it, and then roll +STAT.<br /><br />*On a 12+, hold 2.<br /><br />*On a 10+, hold 1.<br /><br />*On a 7-9, hold 1, but you also encounter a guardian.<br /><br />*On a miss, you encounter a guardian.<br /><br />*On a 1-3, also lose all hold.<br /><br />If multiple party members navigate in turn, their hold is pooled together for the entire party. To find one of the labyrinth’s treasures, spend 1 hold and describe the room it is found in. You may spend 3 hold at any time to find the entrance to the heart of the labyrinth.﻿<br /><br /><del>-----</del>     <del>----</del><br /><br />Also, don&#39;t be afraid if they best the minoutaur and leave the labyrinth quickly as well, you can just have an encounter or two with Sirens, Furies, Pirates or even encounter a cursed island which will hac\ve to be explored next session, or just have them pass the straight of Scylla and Karibdis before going to the questions.<br /></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/109791996665503926061_photo.jpg'> Robert Rendell</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-09 10:59:11 (edited: 2018-09-09 10:59:11)</cite></p>
        <p>As <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/111734437461360625141" oid="111734437461360625141">Michael Esperum</a></span> says, you can abstract the space where the Minotaur is.  Rather than mapping it out on graph paper and then having your players navigate it, you can hand-wave the specific intersection-by-intersection navigation through the maze, throw out some descriptions of the twisting maze to set the scene but focus on when the party finds interesting things.<br /><br />The Labyrinth move above gives you a way to allow the dice to influence the outcomes, so it&#39;s not entirely at the GM&#39;s whim how it plays out.  You&#39;d just prep a few guardians, a few treasures or discoveries, and the heart of the labyrinth, and then let the players have at it.<br /><br />All that said, if you&#39;d rather a more traditional approach, where you have a map and your players navigate intersection-by-intersection, the internet has many labyrinth maps you could yoink.  For example<br />* <a href="http://loottheroom.uk/lubs-labyrinth/" data-embed="CIcDCNACCM8CCAASJWh0dHA6Ly9sb290dGhlcm9vbS51ay9sdWJzLWxhYnlyaW50aC86fAjEmPHv2ywSJWh0dHA6Ly9sb290dGhlcm9vbS51ay9sdWJzLWxhYnlyaW50aC8aJWh0dHA6Ly9sb290dGhlcm9vbS51ay9sdWJzLWxhYnlyaW50aC8iJWh0dHA6Ly9sb290dGhlcm9vbS51ay9sdWJzLWxhYnlyaW50aC_y4t2hAfYECiVodHRwOi8vbG9vdHRoZXJvb20udWsvbHVicy1sYWJ5cmludGgvEmlodHRwczovL2kyLndwLmNvbS9sb290dGhlcm9vbS51ay93cC1jb250ZW50L3VwbG9hZHMvMjAxOC8wMy9MVFItTWFwLUx1YnNMYWJ5cmludGgtTC1OUy5wbmc_Zml0PTkyNyUyQzEyMDAaEUx1YuKAmXMgTGFieXJpbnRoIiRBIGxhYnlyaW50aCBmaXQgZm9yIGEgZ29ibGluIG15c3RpYy7KC-" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">http://loottheroom.uk/lubs-labyrinth/</a><br />* <a href="https://rpgcharacters.wordpress.com/2017/09/15/well-take-the-baby-to-the-goblin-city/" class="ot-anchor">https://rpgcharacters.wordpress.com/2017/09/15/well-take-the-baby-to-the-goblin-city/</a><br />* <a href="https://www.deviantart.com/djekspek/art/Rotating-Madness-156644839" class="ot-anchor">https://www.deviantart.com/djekspek/art/Rotating-Madness-156644839</a><br /></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/106729812339460975235_photo.jpg'> Jeff Wood</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-09 14:00:26 (edited: 2018-09-09 14:00:26)</cite></p>
        <p>Also, a very configurable option is the Dunjon generator: <a href="https://donjon.bin.sh/d20/dungeon/" class="ot-anchor">https://donjon.bin.sh/d20/dungeon/</a><br /><a href="https://donjon.bin.sh/d20/dungeon/" data-embed="CNECCNACCM8CCAASImh0dHBzOi8vZG9uam9uLmJpbi5zaC9kMjAvZHVuZ2Vvbi86Twjrxoj12ywSImh0dHBzOi8vZG9uam9uLmJpbi5zaC9kMjAvZHVuZ2Vvbi8aImh0dHBzOi8vZG9uam9uLmJpbi5zaC9kMjAvZHVuZ2Vvbi_" data-attachment-render-hint="2" class="ot-anchor">https://donjon.bin.sh/d20/dungeon/</a></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/102664254666078826277_photo.jpg'> Stephen Karnes</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-09 15:35:46 (edited: 2018-09-09 15:35:46)</cite></p>
        <p>Perilous Wilds is excellent for creating ‘dungeons.’ It abstracts the concept and presents it more like a countdown clock. Once the party have filled in the clock, they’ve explored the dungeon.</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/110285352867085036435_photo.jpg'> Andrea Serafini</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-09 17:16:02 (edited: 2018-09-09 17:16:02)</cite></p>
        <p>Perhaps this one could help?<br /><br /><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-5jyvW2abdCbD7LWPUyyrYvjFpVLJs4EXJ0jb7dAfNc/edit" data-embed="__X2VzY2FwZWRfZnJhZ21lbnRfPQ" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-5jyvW2abdCbD7LWPUyyrYvjFpVLJs4EXJ0jb7dAfNc/edit</a></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/102236064105876185661_photo.jpg'> Troy Morris</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-10 16:26:21 (edited: 2018-09-10 16:27:26)</cite></p>
        <p>This is great-- thanks everyone!<br /><br />For the vast majority of this campaign, I&#39;ve gotten away without using an actual map and just describing things. I thought it would be fun have a map this time around (especially as a few party members will be on roll20).<br /><br />I think I&#39;ll use the Tesseract sewers for some treasures and monsters, with the Labyrinth move and the Lub&#39;s Labyrinth to provide a visual anchor.<br /><br />This has been a huge help!</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z12thlgb5qzvxtwrm04chdyhevn3yjdqzrk0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/102236064105876185661_photo.jpg'> Troy Morris</h4>
      <p><cite>2018-09-10 16:29:21 (edited: 2018-09-10 16:29:21)</cite></p>
        <p><span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/106729812339460975235" oid="106729812339460975235">Jeff Wood</a></span> That is a great resource! Sometimes, you just need to generate a dungeon to keep the party occupied while you stitch together their actions into a narrative.</p>
</div>
